title: Episode 164 – Kate Wilson, Vail Resorts, VP of Environmental & Social Responsibility
subtitle: [Epic Sustainability, Wellness, & Community Service – Vail Resorts at the Peak of Doing Good]
description: With 42 owned and operated resorts world-wide, Vail Resorts is at the peak of sustainability leadership across its comprehensive suite of environmental, social, employee, and community service initiatives. Moreover, as a “Do Good” values-based company, Vail Resorts leads the way as an example of a competitive, profitable, and growing public company that has woven into its core a deep commitment to social and environmental performance. In this interview, Kate Wilson, VP of Environmental & Social Responsibility discusses Vail’s many core projects, and the fact that, for Vail Resorts, “Sustainability is not a ‘side thing’ … it is integral and operationalized” throughout the corporate ecosystem.

about_sections.about_kate_wilson: As a company rooted in the outdoors, Vail Resorts has a special responsibility to protect the unique mountains where it operates. In her new role as Vice President of Environmental and Social Responsibility, Kate Wilson applies her two decades of experience to leading this critical work. Kate now oversees all four of the company’s responsibility pillars: Sustainability, investing in the future of the industry through Inclusive Access, providing Community Support, and supporting team members through the Employee Foundation. Under her leadership, the company reached 100% renewable electricity across its North American operations for the second consecutive year and is on track to achieve Commitment to Zero – the bold goal to reach a zero net operating footprint by 2030.

segments.text: Music
Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast.
I'm your host, Aaron William Perry,
and today we're visiting with Kate Wilson,
the Vice President of Environmental and Social Responsibility
at Vale Resorts. Kate, it's such a joy to be able to visit with you today.
Thanks so much for having me, I'm excited to be here.
Me too. I'm really excited. We have so many threads and pieces to talk about as it relates to stewardship, sustainability, health and wellness,
in the work that's being done by you and your team at Vale Resorts. It's really extraordinary.
Yeah, I'm excited to cover it all with you today.
Super. As a company rooted in the outdoors,
Vale Resorts has a special responsibility to protect the unique mountains where it operates.
In her new role as Vice President of Environmental and Social Responsibility,
Kate Wilson applies her two decades of experience to leading this critical work.
Kate now oversees all four of the company's responsibility pillars, sustainability,
investing in the future of the industry through inclusive access, providing community support,
and supporting team members through the Employee Foundation.
Under her leadership, the company reached 100% renewable electricity across its North American operations
for the second consecutive year and is on track to achieve commitment to zero,
the bold goal to reach a zero net operating footprint by 2030.
Before her promotion to Vice President in 2023, Kate served as the Senior Director of Sustainability.
Representing Vale Resorts, Kate has led sustainability discussions at the Bloomberg Sustainable Business Summit,
Google's Travel Summit, Colorado Governor's Tourism Conference, and MT 2030, a coalition of mountain towns.
Prior to joining Vale Resorts, Kate developed and led the greenhouse gas and sustainability strategy practice
at the Cadmus Group for 10 years.
She earned her Master of Applied Science in Environmental Policy and Management degree from the University of Denver
and a Bachelor's degree in Environmental Policy from Colby College in Maine.
Kate is the co-lead of Vale Resorts Women and Allies Employee Resource Group,
chairs the National Ski areas Association Environmental Committee, and leads the Mountain Collaborative for Climate Action.
Kate was recognized by the Denver Business Journal in 2020 on the 40 under 40 for her work at Vale Resorts,
and she is also a Director, a board member and past chair of one of our most favorite nonprofits here in the area called Resource Central,
which I look forward to asking you about as well.
So Kate, it's just tremendous to have this opportunity to visit with you and to explore and unpack all of this work that you're doing
through the corporate mechanism of Vale Resorts. Can you tell us a bit about the reach, the geography, the locations of the various properties
and the resorts that you're working with and how that interfaces with different wilderness and ecological systems?
Sure. So thanks for having me. I'm really excited for this conversation.
Yeah, so Vale Resorts, you know, we have now 42 on-dannabrated resorts around the world.
We have three in Australia. We have two in Switzerland. One just closed last week, so we're really excited about that.
And then we have several all over North America, and then of course, Wissor Black Home in Canada.
So pretty much covers the gamut in terms of ecosystems, in terms of habitat, in terms of communities, as well as sort of the availability of, I guess, what I'll call sustainability mechanisms.
So if you think about, we have emissions goals and waste goal and habitat goals. So you think about those are very tailored to each community where we operate.
You know, recycling options, for example, in Pennsylvania might be very different than in Park City. Right? So you think about some of those things.
And so we do have the benefit of sort of a centralized network where we can pilot things at different types of resorts and then think about, okay, now let's roll this out at scale.
That's one of the benefits of the enterprise in that way. And you do have to really be mindful of like, what's the local community dynamics, what types of things are available.
So we get the benefit of that enterprise and sort of still lean into local so that we can figure out how that applies in the best way.

Yeah, I was so struck and impressed reading through and looking through the most recent environmental and social responsibility report and will actually include the link to the document in our show notes.
Your work is covering sustainability, inclusive access, community support and grants, employee foundation, epic wellness program commitment to zero epic progress.
It's to me, I knew already before preparing for our discussion that Vale is doing some good work. But when I saw the report, I was legitimately astonished. I thought, wow, this is so impressive.
And I was hoping you could kind of walk us through the framework in all the different areas where you're having impact and often exceeding the goals and targets you guys have set for yourselves.

Yeah, so I want to be really clear that that's our team's not me. You know, I have the privilege of helping develop the strategy of thinking about, you know, making sure we're hitting, for example, you think about commitment to zero zero net operating footprint by 20%.

So that includes zero net emissions, zero waste to landfill, which is the hardest one and zero net operating impact on forests and habitat. And so you think about, you know, I am sort of in this centralized role thinking about, okay, what's I build out the road maps and the strategy with a couple of key people on my team.
And then just as if, if not more key are those that are in resort that are out there on the ground working with our frontline employees, making these programs come to life.
So I just want to be really clear that I get, I get to be a part of this, but by no means is that progress attributed to me.
So I think that that's, you know, I would, I would kind of zoom out a little bit. And I think the reason why we do this work at Bill Resorts is because it's tied to our do good value.
We are absolutely a values based company. We are, it is not a poster on the wall somewhere in the kitchen that you never see again. It is how we make decisions every day.
It's operationalized and we think about how will this impact all of our, all of our many stakeholders in the environment is one of those.
And so we think about, yeah, all of those pieces. So for me, it was, it's about what do good feels like in each one of those things.
So I feel really privileged that I get to do something that's so aligned with my values of connection, of growth, of developing others.
That's why I do it. So if you think about the way we approach each of those programs, it's from, it's rooted in those values.
So I think that's really important to start with. And then you think about, yeah, so commitment to zero, for example, we had been doing environmental work for a lot longer.
We launched that goal in 2017. We've been doing environmental work since 2006 and before. But more at an individual resort level.
So for example, when I joined about six years ago, I think we had 14 resorts, right? And now in the last six years, we have now 42.
So it's a pretty big jump. So you think about, you know, we had environmental teams. But when we got to 2017, we thought, okay, we've reduced energy by 10% here.
Then we've set another goal. We've helped with restoration after this fire. We've done all these different pieces. But how do we come together and sort of sing from the same sheet music, right?
And make the biggest impact that we can. And so we looked at that and thought, okay, well, rather than thinking about, like, what are the baby steps that we could take to get to somewhere good?
Could we kind of invert that and think about what would it take? What types of goals would it take for companies to set, for us to solve climate change?
And that's how we set commitment to zero. So we thought, okay, could we have a zero net operating impact across this huge enterprise?
Could even as we're growing, right? We knew we would grow. So could we do that? And could we, you know, have this impacted scale?
And so that was how that was how it happened, you know, and we didn't have that day, you know, here in 2017, here's the exact roadmap, right?
We said, okay, we were going to do this. We're serious about it. We dedicated $25 million to the energy efficiency side of that project. And said, okay, here we go.
So the next year we brought this wind farm online. And well, we entered the deal to bring it online. It didn't come online until 2020. Those deals take multiple years.
But really looked at like, okay, we're serious. How do we signal that? What is the thing that we're going to do? And then really started making progress, you know, against that from that point.
And again, using that idea of everybody's kind of looking at the same strategy and then going to their resort and figuring out like, okay, these aren't LED light bulbs yet.
We need to deploy capital to do that. How are we doing with our recycling? Oh, we're in a place where we don't have recycling in our community.
How do we figure that out? So applying that local piece. And then, yeah, from that perspective, right? We are very much on our way. And I'm glad the listeners will get to see that report.
Because, yeah, all of those numbers are pretty impressive about what the teams on the ground have done, right? And bringing the frontline folks into that has been, it's been amazing to watch.

And then I would say, you know, on the responsibility pillar, you know, sort of describe this new umbrella. The reason that we're doing that is we're thinking about sort of the environmental and the social together, right?
And how do we think about having communications in our, in our communities where we're having round tables about community issues that include climate change, right?

How do we bring the sustainability team in with the community team and be really bringing those conversations together to be a strong partner, to be able to share some of our lessons learned with our communities and had these open conversations with them and learn from each other.

So that's really why we brought it together. So yeah, you mentioned some of the other groups, you know, we have our employee foundation, which is something that helps employees and times of need or hardship also provides scholarship grants.
So that's something that we, you know, we really think it's important to take care of our team members. And so that's where that comes from.

And then, you know, the community piece. So this is about, you know, grants and building these bridges and partnerships and real relationships in our communities of what are the challenges we're all facing together.

We believe very strongly we're not going to solve any of this alone, right? And so it will take all of us. So we feel like let's have our bold stance. Let's let's be accountable and make as much difference as we can.

But let's bring others with us and like, where can we partner? Where are we working on the same things? And then, you know, I'm really excited to talk about inclusive access and to talk about diversity, equity and inclusion.
So Arlene now kind of owns the external piece of that. So what that means is, you know, building partnerships with boys and girls club of Chicago with the National Brotherhood of Snow Sports, right?
We firmly believe the future of the sport is inclusion. So how do we build a roadmap to similar to commitment to zero in terms of the approach?

But how do we do that to make sure that we are taking actionable steps, you know, every quarter, right? To make sure that we are shifting that and inviting others into the sport who haven't historically, you know, enjoyed it.

So the inclusive access programs, we do adaptive access, some youth programs, as well as adult access. So you think about, you know, what does that feel like? That's a kid getting off the bus at Wilmot for the first time in seeing the stars, right? That's.
So for me, again, it's about, it's that value coming to life. It's feeling and these programs and all under the responsibility pillar, that's how we're approaching it.
And of like, how do we invite more people in? How do we protect the places where we are? And be a good partner and support our team members and our communities in the meantime?

It's so exciting. I really, I want to emphasize and encourage our audience to check out the report, the environmental and social responsibility part, because I'll tell you what, you know, doing what I do, podcasting and working with the Wired Earth Community Global Network of Ambassadors and others.

You know, I'm directly connected to and hearing from people who are doing all kinds of good and great work and I'll admit this connectivity and knowledge flow helps me not get depressed, helps me stay hopeful, positive, optimistic and energized, moving forward, doing work we can in the social and environmental arenas, and reading through and looking through the report.

It was like, it was a really cool experience for me. It really, it was uplifting. I'll say that. So I want to encourage folks to check that out for sure. And, you know, I'm excited to dig into a few of these threats and I want to just acknowledge, you know, I've been skiing since I was a kid and have skied out many of the veil resorts, ski areas for years and decades.

And I've been a fan of what I've known, veiled to do with a couple of my previous businesses. We actually did business directly with veil resorts on the recycling side and on the food procurement side of things.
This was about a decade or more ago. And so I'm a fan. I'll put that right up on the table. We appreciate you.

Yep. Yep. And one of the things that's really struck me about veil and some of the other leaders in the ski and wilderness tourism, active tourism space is the, I see it almost as a triangle. There's this nexus where ski resorts in particular, this industry in particular is among the most sensitive probably to things like climate change.
And so you've got that going on. You've got the commitments and the incredible systemic work you guys are doing going on. And then for me, the third, uh,

a layer point on the triangle is you have this incredible opportunity for messaging and communication to all of these people from around the world who come to your resorts and wow, what, what an amazing platform, you know, for a systemic change making and I was hoping you could talk with us a bit about that.

Yeah. Yeah. So, you know, I think for us, it's about using our voice for good. It's thinking about, you know, when you sit on the chair left, we have several, you pull the bar down always. And then you have, you know, we have commitment to zero signage, right? So some of the, some of them have a map, some of them have other things, you know, which, what's my epic burger, where am I going to get that for lunch? And that sometimes it's this commitment to zero things. We think it's really important sustainability is not a side thing for us.

It is, it is as important as any of the other business decisions that we make is operationalized. We cap, you know, deploy capital against it, just like we would, you know, go through the same robust process that everything else does. But again, it is, that is part of the reason I joined this company after being a consultant for Fortune 500s. I saw, you know, companies that were doing this the right way and companies that were not.
And so when I was looking for sort of my next thing and I wanted to go in house, my personal sort of mantra has been to make the biggest impact on climate change that I can.
And so I looked at, you know, okay, what, what an amazing opportunity to kind of scale this, right, and think about the impact that you can have knowing also it's a growth company, right?

So we're looking to what's the next thing? How do we bring others in? How do we learn from them? How do we deploy things that we've learned across all of that? So of course, our guests are part of that, right? And if you go to one of our restaurants for lunch, let's say your skiing the back bowl is a veil, right?
You go to 2L, which is I think four miles is the crow flies from the loading dock where eventually the compost is going to land.
So just bringing it to life, you think about, okay, you have a banana a lunch and you put, you know, we have employees that sort the waste because at every location there's different rules.
So we don't expect you as the guest to know you're enjoying your ski vacation, trumpet around your boots. You don't want to be standing there and like, which thing does this go in, right?
So we have an employee take that, put it in the compost, and then you think about, you know, it goes on a haul cat, which we have specially retrofitted the bed to sort of have a dump truck bed.
Which then takes it to the top of the gondola, the gondola takes it down, we've designed a special freight system. So while guests are on the gondola, we have these freight cars that are also loaded.
So it'll take it down to our loading dock. And then underneath the air, well, a hotel, we have a whole station under there where we make sure everything is properly sorted.
It goes into truck off to Vale Honeywagon, which is our compost partner in Vale, turns into compost, and then we buy it back.
And then in the summer, when we do our re-regitation projects, right, we put it back on the land and to regenerate the soil, you know, that we operate on.
So we look for everything to sort of be the circular system. And then we tell the story, right? That's why we want people to read that report, you know, we want to make sure that,

that people are seeing these stories and we're bringing it to life for them of what does that mean? It is not easy to get to zero waste at these places that are, you know, geographically diverse, many are very rural.
It's a real challenge to do, but we think about the actual waste reduction, the efficiency of buying less and bringing only what we need onto the mountain to the first place, right?

We don't need to use diesel to get it up to two elk and then, like, let's just bring only what we need. And then from that place, right, let's make sure it's circular, let's recycle as much as we can compost, as much as we can, and then buy it back, right?

So that, so that it's that closed loop system. So that's part of it, right? That's the sort of on mountain experiential piece. And then while we do that, we have signage everywhere so the guests can understand.

We posted, we can add this in the show notes too. We posted a video on LinkedIn earlier this year of a video of that sort of banana peel journey of going through veil and so we can make sure that that listeners can see that.

But again, to bring it to life of how do you actually make this happen and to share that with others, we actually made that video during a climate conference of mountain towns 20, 30 climate conference in veil last year.
And we took our competitors and the towns with us on the tour to show them, like, here's how you do this. So that's the other piece is that this is not some competitive advantage for us.
Climate change is an existential threat, not only the ski industry, but the world, right? And so we see that as like, okay, if we figure some of these things out, we do not have all the answers.
But if we figure some of these things out, let's share that so that people can catch up more quickly, right? We don't need to have everyone kind of have to pilot it themselves.
And so with that, right in 2019, we started the mountain collaborator for climate action. So it's us, Altara, Boeing, Powder, which we call the Big Four and the ski industry.

I think we represented this point over 76 resorts. And so you think about, right, how we can share lessons learned and bring each other along, you know, on the journey. And so that's really important as well as advocacy.
